ResearchProjectDef.label: Electric Agriculture I
ResearchProjectDef.description: Apply electrical lighting to indoor crop cultivation. Study how incandescent filament lamps can substitute for sunlight in enclosed growing spaces, enabling year-round food production independent of season or weather. Unlocks the incandescent grow lamp — wasteful but accessible.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Electric Agriculture II
ResearchProjectDef.description: Refine indoor grow lighting using halogen tungsten technology. The halogen regenerative cycle allows a higher filament temperature, producing a brighter output with marginally improved efficacy over basic incandescent lamps. Covers a wider grow footprint at the cost of even higher surface temperatures. Unlocks the halogen grow lamp.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Industrial Grow Lighting
ResearchProjectDef.description: Apply high-pressure sodium discharge lamp technology to enclosed horticulture. HPS lamps achieve far greater luminous efficacy than filament-based predecessors by exciting sodium vapour to emit intense orange light. A larger grow area is covered per unit, though the technology still produces considerable waste heat and requires a brief warm-up period. Unlocks the sodium grow lamp.

ResearchProjectDef.label: LED Agronomy
ResearchProjectDef.description: Pioneer the application of solid-state LED emitters to controlled-environment agriculture. Unlike discharge or filament sources, LEDs can target specific wavelengths corresponding to plant photoreceptor absorption peaks, dramatically increasing the proportion of electrical input converted to photosynthetically useful light. Waste heat is reduced by more than half compared to sodium technology. Unlocks the LED grow lamp Mk I.

ResearchProjectDef.label: Advanced Photonic Cultivation
ResearchProjectDef.description: Engineer a high-density photonic array with computer-controlled spectral output. By modelling precise plant photoreceptor responses and dynamically tuning emission wavelengths, nearly all electrical input is converted to photosynthetically active radiation. The resulting system covers the largest grow area of any artificial lamp while generating negligible waste heat — the theoretical ceiling of practical horticultural illumination. Unlocks the advanced LED array.
